[[File:Shavuot papercut.jpg|thumb|Shavuot papercut]] '''Jewish paper cutting''' is a traditional form of [[Jewish]] [[folk art]] made by cutting figures and sentences in paper or [[parchment]]. It is connected with various customs and ceremonies, and associated with holidays and family life. Paper cuts often decorated [[Ketubah|ketubbot]] (marriage contracts), [[Mizrah]]s, and ornaments for festive occasions. Paper cutting was practiced by Jewish communities in both Eastern Europe and North Africa and the Middle East for centuries and has seen a revival in modern times in Israel and elsewhere. == History == [[File:Swiat. Agata Szepe 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Jewish papercut "The World"
by Agata Szepe]] === Origins === The origin of Jewish paper cutting is unclear. [[Ashkenazi Jews]] in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries practiced this type of art. However, Jewish paper cuts can be traced to Jewish communities in Syria, Iraq, and North Africa, and the similarity in the cutting techniques (using a knife) between East European Jews and [[Chinese paper cutting|Chinese paper cutters]], may indicate that the origin goes back even further. Some contend that Ashkenazi paper-cutting may date to the 14th century, though its popularity reached a zenith in the 18th and 19th centuries. The first mention of Jewish paper cutting can be found in the treatise "The fight of the pen and the scissors” by a 14th-century rabbi, Shem Tov ben Isaac ben Ardutiel (1290-1369), who describes how he decided to cut letters in paper when his ink became frozen during a harsh winter. To students of Christian Spanish literary history, Rabbi Shem Tov is known as Santob de Carrion de los Condes, the courtly [[Castilian people|Castilian]] troubadour who composed the Proverbios morales for Pedro the Cruel.{{cite web|last1=Shadur |first1=Joseph |title=Jewish Papercutting: Folk art even the poorest folk could create |url=http://www.myjewishlearning.com/culture/2/Art/History_and_Theory/Jewish_Folk_Art/Jewish_Papercuts.shtml?p=0 |website=My Jewish Learning |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107002727/http://www.myjewishlearning.com/culture/2/Art/History_and_Theory/Jewish_Folk_Art/Jewish_Papercuts.shtml?p=0 |archivedate=2015-01-07 |df= }} Paper cutting as a folk craft gained popularity in the nineteenth century when paper became a cheap material.{{cite web|last=Frankel|first=Giza|title=The Art of the Jewish Papercut |url=http://www.zygmuntfrankel.com/jewishpapercut.html |work=ZygmuntFrankel.com |publisher=Etcetera Editions|year=2002}} Paper cutting was widespread among the [[Jews of Poland]] and [[Jews of Russia|Russia]] in the nineteenth century and the early years of the twentieth century. Jewish paper cuts were also produced in Germany and probably in the Netherlands. Some [[Jews of Italy|Italian Jewish]] [[parchment]] ketubot (marriage contracts) from the late 17th century until the nineteenth century were decorated paper cuts as well as some elaborate scrolls of the [[Book of Esther]]. Similar paper cuttings from Jewish communities North Africa and the Middle East have some characteristic style differences. It was popular among Jews both in eastern and western Europe as well as in Turkey, Morocco, Syria, Bangladesh, Israel, and North America.{{cite book|last=Gołąb|first=Marta|title=Jewish paper-cut = Wycinanka żydowska|year=2006|publisher=Wydawnictwo "Hagada"|location=Kraków|isbn=9788391507605}} In North Africa and the Middle East paper cuts were called a "Menorah", because one or more [[Menorah (Temple)|menorah]], always appeared as the central motif. These paper cuts included many inscriptions, mostly on the arms of the candelabras. The paper was mounted on thin, colored metal sheets. Two distinct kinds were produced: a Mizrah and smaller paper cuts used as charms. The motifs are the same as in European Jewish paper cuts but they have a distinctive Eastern style. Also, the [[hamsa]] ("the five-finger hand"), unknown in Europe, very often appears on these paper cuts. === Disappearance === Jewish paper cutting began disappearing in the first half of the twentieth century, mainly because of the rapid assimilation trends and the waning of many traditional practices, and was practiced only by older people who remembered this art form from their youth. Many paper cuts collections that had been preserved were destroyed during [[World War II]] and [[the Holocaust]] and relatively few remain in public or private collections. === Resurgence === Since the late twentieth century, Jewish paper cuts have again become a popular art form in both [[Israel]] and other countries. Paper cutting is again often used to decorate [[ketubot]], wedding invitations, and works of art. To a limited extent, Jewish paper cuts have become more popular in Poland as a result of the [[Jewish Culture Festival in Kraków]], a festival that has been held in [[Kraków]] since the 1990s. [[Beit Hatefutsot]] – The Museum of the Jewish People in [[Tel Aviv, Israel]] presented a 2009 exhibition called "The Revival of Jewish Papercuts: Jewish paper cut art" in October 2009. The exhibit was curated by Prof. Olga Goldberg, Gabriella Rabbi, Rina Biran, the Giza Frenkel Papercut Archive, the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. Additionally, a [[National Science Foundation]]-funded study called “Tradition and Continuity in Jewish Papercuts” was conducted by Prof. Olga Goldberg.{{cite web|title=The Revival of Jewish Papercuts: Jewish paper cut art|url=http://www.bh.org.il/event/revival-jewish-papercuts/|publisher=The Museum of the Jewish People at Beit Hatfutsot |location=Tel Aviv, Israel|date=October 1, 2009 – January 31, 2010}} Artist Oren Loloi writes that the art of Jewish papercutting's resurgence is due in large part to the efforts of Polish-Jewish anthropologist and ethnologist Giza Frankel (see below).{{cite web|last1=Loloi|first1=Oren|title=What is Jewish paper-cutting?|url=https://www.papercutsbyoren.com/jewish-papercutting/|website=Paper Cuts by Oren|accessdate=14 May 2018}} [http://www.worldcat.org/title/migzerot-neyar-omanut-yehudit-amamit/oclc/27227163 Frankel's 1983 book], ''The Art of the Jewish Papercut'' (Migzerot neyar: omanut Yehudit amamit), was produced after 50 years of painstaking research. Today, Jewish papercut art has grown in popularity beyond ritual items to art and expressions of Jewish faith, not only in Israel but worldwide. Loloi contends that the resurgence in papercutting's popularity is in part due to its contemporary near-ubiquity as part of the [[ketubah]] (marriage contract), which is a contemporary site of ''hiddur mitzvah'', the Jewish principle of honouring the Divine by beautifying ritual objects. Contemporary papercutting art may also be seen in amulets like [[Hamsa|hamsas]], [[Birkat HaBayit|blessings for the home]], [[Mizrah#Mizrah_in_Jewish_homes|mizrahim]], and other art pieces, usually as a wall plaque. == Artists == [[File:Jewish papercutting.JPG|thumb|Jewish papercutting]] [[File:Yehudit Shadur Family Tree Book Cover.jpg|thumb|Family tree booklet cover artwork created by Yehudit Shadur]] === Giza Frankel === In Israel papercutting was reactivated by Giza Frankel, a Polish-born ethnographer.{{cite web|title=Frenkel (Frankel), Giza (1895 Wieliczka - 1984 Hajfa)|url=http://www.lauder.pl/frenkel-frankel-giza|work=Lauder Dzieje Żydów}} Frankel's most significant publications on paper cutting are ''Wycinanka żydowska w Polsce'' and ''Art of the Jewishpaper-cut.''{{cite journal|last=Goldberg-Munkiewicz|first=Olga|title=Giza Frankel - Migzerot Nijar Omanut Jehudit Amamit Giwataiim 1983, wyd. Masada |url=http://www.cyfrowaetnografia.pl/Content/3342/Strony+od+PSL_XLIII_nr1-2-23_recenzje.pdf}} Giza Frankel brought knowledge of Polish Jewish paper cuts with her when she emigrated to Israel in 1950.{{cite journal|last=Goldberg-Mulkiewicz|first=Olga|title=Dr Giza Frenkel (Frankel) 16.09. 1895 Wieliczka - 17.05.1984 Haifa|page=139 |url=http://www.cyfrowaetnografia.pl/Content/3343/Strony+od+PSL_XLIII_nr1-2-24_wspomnienie.pdf}} According to Frankel, the most famous Polish papercutters are [[:pl:Marta Gołąb|Marta Gołąb]] and [[:pl:Monika Krajewska|Monika Krajewska]]. === Marta Gołąb === Marta Gołąb is both a graphic artist and papercutter.{{cite web|title=Marta Gołąb z Krakowa: "Wycinanki Żydowskie": 12.09 - 11.10.2002 |url=http://jasnet.pl/ciasna/golab/index.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125023500/http://jasnet.pl/ciasna/GOLAB/INDEX.HTM |archivedate=2012-01-25 |df= }} Her papercuts were exhibited in the Jewish Museum (Wien) Skirball Cultural Center, (Los Angeles), in Emanu-El Synagogue (San Francisco), in the Synagogue in Grobzig (Germany) and on the [[Jewish Culture Festival in Krakow]]. === Monika Krajewska === Monika Krajewska's interests was focus on symbols related both to Jewish papercut and sepulchral art, according to [[:pl:Wycinanka żydowska|Wycinanka żydowska]]. She is a member of [http://www.papercutters.org/ The Guild of American Papercuters].{{cite web|last=Krajewska|first=Monika|title=Wycinanka żydowska|url=http://free.art.pl/mklwww/imprezy/jarmark/2006/wycinanka.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114083211/http://free.art.pl/mklwww/imprezy/jarmark/2006/wycinanka.htm|archivedate=January 14, 2010}} === Yehudit and Joseph Shadur === Yehudit Shadur was a Jewish paper cutting artist.{{cite web|title=Yehudit Shadur |url=http://cyclamensandswords.com/art_august_2010_yehudit_shadur.php |work=Cyclamens and Swords Publishing}}{{cite web|title=December: Judith - Some Highlighted Judiths: Yehudit Shadur|url=http://jwa.org/discover/throughtheyear/december/judith/bios#shadur|work=Jewish Women's Archive}} Yehudit Shadur and her husband Joseph Shadur wrote a history of the last three centuries of Jewish paper cutting called ''Traditional Jewish Papercuts: An Inner World of Art and Symbol.'' They won a 1994 Jewish National Book Council prize for this book.{{cite web|title=NJBA Winners |url=http://www.jewishbookcouncil.org/awards/njba-list|work=Jewish Book Council}}{{cite web|title=Artists - Yehudit Shadur|url=http://www.artatthecenter.com/HTML/Artists.cfm?ID=2|work=Art at the Center - Judaica Gallery|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206071833/http://www.artatthecenter.com/HTML/Artists.cfm?ID=2|archivedate=February 6, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Beck|first=Mordechai|title=Obituaries: Yehudit Shadur|url=https://www.princeton.edu/music/news/JC_2503_32C.pdf|newspaper=The Jewish Chronicle (TheJC.com)|date=March 25, 2011|location=Jerusalem}} In addition to this book, the Shadurs wrote an additional book on Jewish papercuts, the catalog on Yehudit Shadur's 1995 exhibit at the Haaretz Museum in Ramat Aviv, Israel, and several articles on the art of Jewish papercutting. === Tsirl Waletzky === Tsirl Waletzky (née Tsirl Grobla) was considered to be a major contemporary paper cutting artist in American Yiddish culture.{{cite news|title=Tsirl Waletzky: Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?pid=154963196|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 10, 2011}} Waletzky’s papercuts differed from "traditional forms in that they are free flowing and less bound to structure and symmetry."{{cite news|last=Gottesman|first=Itzik|title=Tsirl Waletzky, Papercutting Pioneer, Dies at 90|url=http://forward.com/articles/147962/tsirl-waletzky-papercutting-pioneer-dies-at-/|newspaper=The Jewish Daily Forward|date=December 13, 2011|format=obituary}} === Kim Phillips === [https://www.hebrica.com/ Kim Phillips] is a modern Jewish paper cut artist whose work pushes the limits of interpretation of Jewish texts and themes without reference to traditional symmetrical forms. Her work has been exhibited in Israel and in the United States. === Oren Loloi === Oren Loloi (Papercuts By Oren), is a modern Jewish paper cut artist working in Israel.{{cite web|title=About the Artist|url=https://www.papercutsbyoren.com/}} His work belongs to a new aesthetic that bridges the gap between Jewish tradition and the modern resurgence of paper cutting worldwide. His work mainly focuses on ketubot. He has also been commissioned by synagogues in New York and Virginia for large scale works.{{cite web|title=Custom Cut Ketubot and More - Papercuts by Oren|url=http://www.allthingspaper.net/2013/09/custom-cut-ketubot-and-more-papercuts.html}} == Uses == [[Image:Mizrah.jpg|thumb|right|300 pxs|''Mizrah'' papercut, [[Eastern Europe]], 19th century]] === Types === Depending on their purpose, shape and connection with specific religious and non-religious events, paper cuts are of different types.{{cite book|last=Fränklowa|first=Giza|title=Wycinanka zydowska w Polsce: (Papierschnitte bei den Juden in Polen)|year=1929 |publisher=Nakł Towarzystwa Ludoznawczego |location=Lwów |url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/10628388|language=Polish}}{{rp|40–57}} A Mizrah (hebr. The East) is a plaque hung on the east wall of private houses to show the direction of Jerusalem. A shivis’i (hebr. always) is similar to a mizrah, but it hangs on the east side of a synagogue. Its name is connected with a sentence from the Bible: 'Shivis'i adonai l'negdi tamid' ('I have set the LORD always before me').{{rp|4}} Shivis’i in the form of paper cuts rather than some more durable material were only used in poor synagogues. There were also various paper cuts made for special, religious celebrations. Shevuoslekh ("little Shavuots") and ''royzelekh'' (rosettes) decorated windows for [[Shavuot]]. Royzelekh are circle-shaped paper cuts, while Shevuoslekh are rectangular. They were often made by pupils in elementary Jewish religious schools ([[Cheder]]s). They were sometimes decorated with motifs unconnected to religion, such as soldiers or riders. Flags for [[Simchat Torah|Simchat-Torah]] were also made by ''cheder'' pupils. Created from colourful paper, each paper cut symbolized one of the twelve tribes of Israel. The other side of the paper showed an image of Torah with moving doors cut in paper. Paper cuts made for Sukkot were formed into lanterns, chains and birds, hung in [[Sukkah]]s. Paper cuts often decorated a plaque with a prayer called Ushpizin, made for Sukkot. Paper cuts were also created for Purim, often containing the Hebrew sentence: ”Mishenekhnas adar marbin b’simcha’ (‘We should rejoice because (the month of) Adar begins') and cut into an image of a bottle and glasses, a symbol of rejoicing.{{rp|11}} Papercutting also has connections with other forms of Jewish tradition. For example, [[Ketubah]]s (marriage agreements) were sometimes prepared in the form of paper cut, or decorated with paper cutting elements. Also cut into paper, memorial plaques were made to commemorate the names of ancestors’ names and dates of birth and death. Lanterns with papercut walls were placed in synagogues for anniversaries of great men’s death.{{rp|10–11}} Amulets like a [[Hamsa]] often showed an image of a palm with an eye on it. == Characteristics == === Features === Paper cuts traditionally were created with the use of shoemaker’s knife. It is likely that most artists were men, though in later years, schoolgirls (and boys) made little rosettes (called ''royzelekh'' or ''reyzelekh'' in [[Yiddish]]) with scissors, to decorate their notebooks or for holiday decorations in the home.{{cite web|last1=Michlic|first1=Joanna Beata|title=Toys and Games|url=http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/article.aspx/Toys_and_Games|website=YIVO Encyclopedia of Jews in Eastern Europe|accessdate=14 May 2018}} The artist first drew the pattern on a paper or parchment, and then cut it. Sometimes, they painted their work in watercolors. Paper cuts were usually glued to a contrasting background in a specific way, to bring the cut paper into relief. Hebrew sentences were important element of the composition. The words were either cut or drawn on paper. Elements of [[micrography]], another traditional type of Jewish folk art, can be seen in these blocks of text created with the artist's knife. Due to [[Aniconism in Judaism|Judaism's aniconism]], it is rare to see a paper-cut from this period that depicts the human figure. Exceptions are Sephardic [[Ketubot]] depicting the bride and bridegroom. === Styles === Traditionally, paper cuts made by [[Sephardic]] and Ashkenazi Jews differed from each other. Ashkenazi papercuts were rich, highly detailed, and colourful. In this style, artists tried to fill the free space with as many elements as is possible. By contrast, the Sephardic compositions were more minimalist, including motifs such as the menorah, columns, [[Arabesque|arabesques]] and lanterns. Modern Jewish paper cut art is done in many styles and is not limited to the aforementioned symbols and motifs. They may be single-layered or multi-layered. [[File:Cztery Zwierzęta. Agata Szepe 2011.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Jewish papercut "Four Animals"
by Agata Szepe]] === Symbols === Every element of Jewish paper cut has its own symbolism. Some are typical of general Jewish culture, others are peculiar to the art of paper cutting. The most important symbols are placed along the [[axis of symmetry]]. The main symbols are usually a [[Torah]] or a [[Menorah (Temple)|Menorah]]: * The image of the Torah symbolizes God’s law, Judaism, Israel. The [[Star of David]] symbolizes Judaism and Israel * The Menorah symbolizes Israel, Judaism, and [[Temple in Jerusalem]]. The middle flame is a symbol of ‘[[Shekinah]]’ (Hebrew for God’s presence); the other flames are shown as leaning towards the main flame. The bottom of the menorah is often shown as a complicated ornament symbolizing [[infinity]] A range of animals are depicted in paper cuts: * [[Lions]], a biblical symbol of the [[Tribe of Judah]], are associated with strength, bravery, power{{cite web|title="Mizrah" Papercut for a Succah - Litin, Ukraine - 1858|url=http://kehilalinks.jewishgen.org/litin/papercut.html|work=Litin, Ukraine|publisher=JewishGen|format=KehilaLinks}} * [[Deer]] symbolize the [[Tribe of Naphtali]]{{rp|6}}{{cite web|last=Mael|first=Rabbi Fishel|title=Characteristics of the Tribe of Naphtali|url=http://www.britam.org/mael/Mael13Naphtali.html|work=Shivtei Yisrael|publisher=Brit-Am}} * [[Birds]] are associated with the human soul * [[Fish]] are usually connected with fertility * A [[squirrel]] biting a nut symbolizes the effort put into reading the Torah * The Four Animals (a [[leopard]], an [[eagle]], a [[gazelle]], and a [[lion]]) are connected with a sentence from [[Pirkei Avot]]: “Be strong as the leopard, swift as the eagle, fleet as the gazelle, and brave as the lion to do the will of your Father in Heaven”{{cite web|title=Mishnah Pirkei Avot|url=http://www.shechem.org/torah/avot.html#chap5|work=Ethics Of The Fathers|location=Chapter 5, Number 23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190001/http://www.shechem.org/torah/avot.html#chap5|archivedate=2007-09-27|df=}} * A [[snake eating its own tail]] symbolizes [[infinity]] Papercut flora is usually connected with the biblical [[Tree of Life]],{{rp|6}} with some of the plants having their specific symbolism. For example, [[vine]] was associated with the land of Israel and with fertility, [[pomegranates]] symbolized fertility, etc. Others symbols were connected both with tradition and with everyday life: * [[Signs of the Zodiac]] showed the sequence of Jewish celebrations during the year * Often positioned above the Torah or a Menorah, the crown is a symbol of God, the Torah, the Kingdom of Israel or the Priesthood{{rp|5}} * Columns and other [[wikt:architectonic|architectonic]] elements are associated with the Temple in Jerusalem * Hands with joined thumbs are a gesture of blessing * A jug filled with water and a bowl symbolize the [[Tribe of Levi]], blessing or the Priesthood == Methodology == The images are created by cutting a design into a folded piece of paper. When the paper is unfolded, the symmetrical design is revealed.{{cite web|last=Shadur|first=Yehudit|title=How Yehudit Shadur Makes a Paper-Cut|url=http://members.bib-arch.org/publication.asp?PubID=BSBR&Volume=2&Issue=2&ArticleID=14|work=BR (Bible Review)|date=Summer 1986}} The paper can be cut using either scissors or a craft knife. == Gallery == File:Shavuot papercut.jpg|Shavuot papercut

{{About|the UK Member of Parliament|the philosopher and theologian|John Hick}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = John Hick, [[Esquire|Esq]]., JP | image = John Hick (MP) colour.jpg | alt = | caption = May 1861 by [[Francis Grant (artist)|Francis Grant]] [[Royal Academy of Arts|RA]] (1803–1878) | birth_name = | birth_date = 2 July 1815 | birth_place = [[Bolton]], [[Lancashire]], [[England]] | death_date = {{d-da|2 February 1894|2 July 1815}} | death_place = [[Whalley, Lancashire]], England | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Civil and Mechanical engineer
Politician
Company director }} '''John Hick''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|JP|DL|MP|FRSA}} (2 July 1815 – 2 February 1894) was a wealthy English [[industrialist]], [[art collector]] and [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] politician who sat in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] from 1868 to 1880.{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=John Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg04.htm#73|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}} He is associated with the improvement of [[steam-engine]]s for [[cotton mill]]s and the work of his firm Hick, Hargreaves and Co. universal in countries where [[fibre]] was [[Spinning (textiles)|spun]] or [[fabrics]] [[Power loom|woven]]. ==Family== Hick was the eldest son of [[Benjamin Hick]] (1790–1842), a civil and mechanical engineer{{cite web|last=Unknown|title=OBITUARY. BENJAMIN HICK, BORN 1790|url=http://www.icevirtuallibrary.com/doi/pdf/10.1680/imotp.1843.24570|work=Minutes of the Proceedings |volume=2 |issue=1843|pages=12|date=1 January 1843 |issn=1753-7843 |publisher=Institution of Civil Engineers|accessdate=14 December 2012|doi=10.1680/imotp.1843.24570}} responsible for improvements to the steam-engine, and his wife Elizabeth Routledge (1783–1826), daughter of William Routledge of [[Elvington, City of York|Elvington]] Yorkshire. Elizabeth's brother and Hick's uncle, [[Joshua Routledge]] (1773–1829) also an engineer living in [[Bolton]], designed the ''Engineer's Improved [[Slide Rule]]'' and [[patented]] improvements to the Rotary Steam Engine.{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Benjamin Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg03.htm#72|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=William Routledge|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg03.htm#56|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Joshua Routledge|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg02.htm#50|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite journal|last1=Routledge|first1=Joshua|title=Improvement or Improvements upon the Rotary Steam Engine|journal=Repertory of Arts, Manufactures, and Agriculture |date=August 1818|volume=XXXIII – Second Series |pages=129–133|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dO80AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=joshua+routledge+rotary+steam+engine#v=onepage&q=joshua%20routledge%20rotary%20steam%20engine&f=false|accessdate=26 November 2015|publisher=G. and T. Wilkie|location=[[University of Michigan]], USA }} ==Education and early career== Educated at a [[private school]] near [[Alderley, Cheshire|Alderley]], Cheshire and [[Bolton School|Bolton Grammar School]]{{cite news|title=HICK(Bolton)|issue=26299|publisher=The Times|date=4 Dec 1868|page=3}} where he received a commercial and [[Classical education movement|classical education]], Hick entered Benjamin Hick's Soho Works from school and from a young age, management of the Bolton engineering firm [[B. Hick and Sons|Benjamin Hick and Son]] with his father. Following Benjamin Hick's death in 1842, Hick became senior partner in the family business, later Hick, Hargreaves, & Co and a member of the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] in 1845. He was [[Church Warden]] for [[James Slade]],{{cite book|last1=Hardman|first1=Malcolm|title=Classic Soil: Community, Aspiration, and Debate in the Bolton Region of Lancashire, 1819-1845|date=2003|publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press|isbn=9780838639665|page=311|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dx6gXAU-bc0C&pg=PA311&lpg=PA311&dq=john+hick+church+warden+slade#v=onepage&q=john%20hick%20church%20warden%20slade&f=false|accessdate=4 December 2015|ref=15 |chapter=NOTES TO CHAPTERS 14 AND 15}} [[School governor|Governor of]] [[Grammar School|Bolton Grammar School]], [[Town councillor]] for nine years from 1844, a member of the [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]], founder member of the [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] from 1847 until 1852, member of the London Association of [[Shop foreman|Foreman]] Engineers and [[Draughtsman]],{{cite news|title=FOREMEN ENGINEERS AND DRAUGHTSMEN |issue=28263|publisher=The Times|date=15 March 1875|page=10}} [[National Society for Promoting Religious Education|National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church in England and Wales]],{{cite journal|journal=Thirtieth Annual Report of the NATIONAL SOCIETY FOR PROMOTING FOR PROMOTING THE EDUCATION OF THE POOR IN the Principles of the Established Church THROUGHOUT ENGLAND AND WALES | title=Thirtieth Annual Report |date=1841|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_LYEAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=26 November 2015|location=Oxford University}} Justice of the Peace for the [[County Borough of Bolton|Borough of Bolton]] and [[Salford (hundred)|Salford Hundred]], liberal [[patron]] of the [[fine arts]][https://archive.org/stream/debrettshouseo1870londuoft#page/142/mode/2up Debretts House of Commons and the Judicial Bench 1870] and a director of the [[London and North Western Railway]] under the chairmanship of [[Richard Moon (1814–1899)|Sir Richard Moon]] and [[Richard Grosvenor, 1st Baron Stalbridge|Lord Stalbridge]], from 1871 until his death.{{cite magazine|last1=Dunn|first1=J.M. |title=F.W. Webb, Crewe |magazine=Railway Magazine|date=1961|volume=107|pages=756–762, 840–844|url=http://www.steamindex.com/people/webb.htm|accessdate=1 December 2015}} In 1839 (age 23) while working for B. Hick and Son, John Hick Jr as he was referred to at the time, was awarded the Silver Medal by the [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]] for his novel invention of an expanding [[mandrel]] for turning [[lathes]], it was an adaptation of a principle developed by [[Marc Brunel]] for [[pully]] [[Block (sailing)|block]] manufacture at [[Portsmouth Block Mills|Portsmouth]] and received the praise of three eminent engineers; [[Bryan Donkin]], [[Joshua Field (engineer)|Joshua Field]] and [[John Rennie the Younger|John Rennie]].{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=No. XI. EXPANDING MANDREL|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1839|volume=LIII|pages=87–92|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326867/41326867#page/n1/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=JSTOR}} During 1842 Hick was awarded a second silver medal by the Society of Arts for his invention of an [[Elliptograph]]; conceived in 1840,{{cite web|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=Elliptograph devised in 1840 by John Hick of Bolton|url=https://collection.sciencemuseum.org.uk/objects/co60100/elliptograph-devised-in-1840-by-john-hick-of-bolto-curve-drawing-instruments-ellipsographs|website=Science Museum Group|accessdate=10 November 2016|date=1840}} the device provided a simple and accurate solution for the drawing ''[[ellipse|ellipsoid forms]]'' of various proportions. Hick received further praise from [[James Nasmyth]], [[William Fairbairn]], [[Joseph Whitworth]], and amongst others, [[Charles Holtzapffel]], Chairman of the Committee of Mechanics. Models of both devices were placed in the Society's repository.{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=NO. II. ELLIPTOGRAPH|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1843|volume=LIV|pages=8–13|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326879/41326879#page/n1/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=JSTOR}} Hick contributed a paper to the Institute of Mechanical Engineers in 1849 on a friction [[clutch]] ''for connecting and disconnecting the driving power with shafts and machinery''. A B. Hick and Son, 1:12 [[Scale (ratio)|scale]] [[patent model]] of ''disconnecting apparatus, for [[screw propeller]]s'', c. 1855 is held in the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] [[Marine propulsion|marine engines]] collection.{{cite web|last1=B. Hick & Son|title=Model of disconnecting apparatus, for screw propellers.|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?type=related&kv=39375&t=objects|website=Science Museum Group|accessdate=11 November 2016|date=c. 1855}} ==Marriage== John Hick married Margaret Bashall (1824–1872), eldest daughter of [[industrialist]] William Bashall, partner in [[Bashall & Boardman]] of [[Farington]] Lodge, near [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] on 24 June 1846,{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Brian|title=The Middlemost and the Milltowns: Bourgeois Culture and Politics in Early Industrial England|year=2001|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-4174-3 |page=361|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3vqbJLHsbIMC&pg=PA361&lpg=PA361&dq=Benjamin+Hick+patron#v=onepage&q=Benjamin%20Hick%20patron&f=false}}{{cite web|title=The Victorians: The Directory of the Cotton Mills of South Ribble |url=https://south-ribble.co.uk/srmuseum/pages/schools/05_directory_of_mills.pdf |website=South Ribble Primary Schools Local History Project |publisher=[[South Ribble Museum & Exhibition Centre]] |accessdate=1 December 2015 |page=5 }} they raised four daughters. Following Margaret Hick's death in 1872,{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Margaret Bashall|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg04.htm#73|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}} Hick married the sister of his son-in-law, Rebecca Maria Ashworth (1838–1908), eldest daughter of [[Edmund Ashworth]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]] (1800–1881) of [[Egerton, Greater Manchester|Egerton]] Hall on 16 December 1874 at [[Clapham Sect|Holy Trinity Church]], [[Clapham]]; the couple were married by Margaret Hick's cousin and brother-in-law [[Reverend]] William Bashall (1830–1902), Vicar of [[St Mary the Virgin's Church, Deane|Deane]], Lancashire, by special licence from the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Archibald Tait]].{{cite web|title=Marriage Registration|website=Ancestry.com|page=183|date=16 December 1874}} Edmund Ashworth was a cotton manufacturer, proprietor of E. Ashworth & Sons and Egerton Mill, founder member of the [[Anti-Corn Law League]] with his brother [[Henry Ashworth (nonconformist)|Henry Ashworth]] (1794–1880){{cite web|title=A history of the Ashworth family|url=http://egertonvillage.medianewsonline.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=7|work=Egerton Village Online – Bolton Lancashire|accessdate=29 December 2012}} JP, in association with [[John Bright]] and [[Richard Cobden]] (Henry Ashworth's brother-in-law), and supporter of reforming, [[abolitionism in the United Kingdom|anti-slavery]] and peace organisations.{{cite web|title=Edmund Ashworth|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/ashworth-e.html|website=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=11 November 2015}} The Ashworths are both thought to have been Oswald Millbank in [[Benjamin Disraeli]]'s novel [[Coningsby (novel)|''Coningsby'']].{{cite book|last1=Axon|first1=William Edward Armytage|title=THE ANNALS OF MANCHESTER, A CHRONOLOGICAL RECORD FROM THE EARLIEST TIMES TO THE END OF 1885|date=1886|publisher=John Heywood, Deansgate and Ridgefield|page=380|url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsmancheste00axongoog#page/n404/mode/1up/search/edmund+ashworth|accessdate=11 November 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Grindon|first1=Leo Hartley|title=LANCASHIRE, HISTORICAL & PICTORIAL NOTES|date=1892|publisher=SEELY & CO., LIMITED|url=http://www.mirrorservice.org/sites/gutenberg.org/4/0/5/8/40584/40584-h/40584-h.htm#FNanchor_22_22|chapter=Footnotes [22]}}{{cite book|last1=Musson|first1=A. E. |title=Enterprise in Soap and Chemicals: Joseph Crosfield & Sons, Limited 1815–1965|date=1965|publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] |page=133|url=https://books.google.com/?id=TsG8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA133&lpg=PA133&dq=henry+ashworth+oswald+millbank#v=onepage&q=henry%20ashworth%20oswald%20millbank&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Eccleshall|first1=Robert|title=English Conservatism Since the Restoration: An Introduction and Anthology|date=11 Sep 2002|publisher=Routledge|url=https://books.google.com/?id=K-GKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT305&lpg=PT305&dq=Henry+Ashworth+Disraeli#v=onepage&q=Henry%20Ashworth%20Disraeli&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015|chapter=Sir Rhodes Boyson (1925-)|isbn=9781134997749}}{{cite book|last1=Roberts|first1=F. David|title=The Social Conscience of the Early Victorians|date=2002|publisher=Stanford University Press, Stanford, California|isbn=0-8047-4532-3|page=68|url=http://graduateinstitute.ch/files/live/sites/iheid/files/sites/mia/shared/mia/cours/IA023/Week%204/Roberts_The_Social_Conscience_of_the_Early_Victorians.pdf|accessdate=11 November 2015}} The two families (Hick and Ashworth) were linked by marriage in 1868 when Hick's first child and eldest daughter Margaret (1847–1929) married Edmund Ashworth Jr (1833–1901).{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Margaret Elizabeth Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg21.htm#92|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Edmund Ashworth Jnr|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/ashworth-e-2.html|website=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=2015}} The "highly respected" Reverend Bashall retired to the position of [[curate]] at [[St Barnabas's, Kensington|St Barnabas church]], [[Addison Road, London|Addison Road]], [[Kensington]] from about 1876{{cite book|last1=Bishop M.A. |first1=Rev. Kenneth M. |title=Dean Church|date=1952|url=http://www.deanechurch.co.uk/Library/Guides/1952.pdf|page=38|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Census|website=Ancestry.com|ref=R.G. 11 28|location=Public Record Office|page=4|date=1881}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Farrer |editor2-last=Bronbill |editor1-first=William | editor2-first=J. |title=THE VICTORIA HISTORY OF THE COUNTY OF LANCASTER|date=1911|publisher=LONDON CONSTABLE AND COMPANY LIMITED|pages=4–5|url=https://archive.org/stream/victoriahistoryo05farruoft#page/4/mode/2up/search/curate+of+st+barnabas's|accessdate=2 December 2015|chapter=TOPOGRAPHY, THE HUNDRED OF SALFORD, DEAN}} remaining in the area until his death, 1902.{{cite web|title=Census|website=Ancestry.com|ref=R.G. 13/22|location=Public Record Office|page=18|date=1901}}{{cite web|last1=Crangle|first1=Richard|title=Person record: BASHALL, Reverend W. (1829-1902)|url=http://www.slides.uni-trier.de/person/index.php?id=6003104|website=LUCERNA – the Magic Lantern Web Resource|accessdate=18 November 2015}} ==The Great Exhibition== [[File:Bolton Iron and Steel Company certificate.jpg|thumb|Bolton Iron and Steel Company certificate describing,''"[[Railway tires|STEEL TYRES]], DECARBONIZED STEEL, BOILER & [[Firebox (steam engine)|FIREBOX]] PLATES, RAILS ANGLES & BARS & GENERAL FORGINGS IN STEEL & [[Wrought iron|WROUGHT IRON]], HEAVY SOLID [[Steel casting|CAST STEEL]] [[Anvil|ANVIL]]S. HEAVY CASTINGS IN STEEL."'', showing the [[James Nasmyth#The steam hammer|Nasmyth steam hammer]] and a [[2-2-2]] steam locomotive.]] 1851 saw the [[Crystal Palace Exhibition]] in [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]]; early in 1850 [[Mayor of Bolton]], [[Thomas Lever Rushton]] (1810–1883) was appointed chairman of a committee to organise the town's efforts toward the Exhibition and presented as a Local Commissioner to [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]] at [[St James's Palace]] 18 March 1850.{{cite web|title=Thomas Lever Rushton|url=http://heritagearchives.rbs.com/people/list/thomas-lever-rushton.html|website=RBS Heritage Hub|publisher=Royal Bank of Scotland 2015|accessdate=2 May 2015}} While the family business of Benjamin Hick and Son displayed machinery{{cite book|title=Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of all Nations, 1851. OFFICIAL DESCRIPTIVE AND ILLUSTRATED CATALOGUE. Vol I. SECTION II. CLASSES 5 TO 10|date=1851|page=268|url=https://archive.org/stream/b21495361_0001#page/n525/mode/2up|accessdate=21 November 2015|chapter=[[Platt Brothers|HIBBERT, PLATT & SONS]]}} and engineering models in the [[The Crystal Palace|Crystal Palace]],{{cite book|title=Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of all Nations, 1851. CLASSES 5 TO 10|date=1851|page=293|url=https://archive.org/stream/b21495361_0001#page/n549/mode/2up|accessdate=21 November 2015|chapter=HICK, B., & SON, Bolton — Designers and Manufacturers }}{{cite book|title=GREAT EXHIBITION 1851. OFFICIAL DESCRIPTIVE AND ILLUSTRATED CATALOGUE. Vol I. SECTION II. CLASSES 5 TO 10|date=1851|page=45|url=https://archive.org/stream/b21495361_0001#page/n245/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=21 November 2015|chapter=LIST OF JURORS }}{{cite journal| title=REPORT OF VISCOUNT CANNING, PRESIDENT OF THE COUNCIL OF CHAIRMEN OF JURIES, ON PRESENTING THE AWARDS OF THE JURIES TO THE ROYAL COMMISSION |journal=The London Gazette|date=17 October 1851|page=2596|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/21254/page/2596/data.pdf|accessdate=20 November 2015}} Condition 6. of the Exhibition's ''Decisions Regarding Juries'' restricted Jurors from competing for prizes in the Class to which they were appointed; prizes could not be awarded to the individual or the companies the Juror represented.{{cite book|title=Reports by the juries on the subjects in the thirty classes into which the exhibition was divided.|date=1852|publisher=London: : Spicer Brothers, wholesale stationers; : W. Clowes and Sons, printers; contractors to the Royal Commission, Tudor Street, New Bridge Street, Blackfriars.|location=Getty Research Institute|page=iii|url=https://archive.org/stream/reportsbyjurieso00grea#page/n11/mode/2up/search/jurors|accessdate=2 January 2018|chapter=Appendix A: DECISIONS REGARDING JURIES}} In 1855 Hick exhibited two pieces from his collection of art works: ''The [[Stag]] Hunt''{{cite journal|last1=Great Britain. Imperial commission, Paris universal exhibition|journal=Paris universal exhibition, 1855. Catalogue of the works exhibited in the British section of the exhibition, in French and English; together with exhibitors' prospectuses, prices current, &c. |date=1855|page=84|title=FINE ARTS DIVISION |url=https://archive.org/stream/parisuniversale01goog#page/n98/mode/2up/search/hunt|accessdate=13 November 2015|publisher=London, Chapman and Hall|location=University of Michigan}} and ''[[Lady Jane Grey]] and [[Roger Ascham]]'' by [[John Callcott Horsley]] in the Fine Art Division of the [[Exposition Universelle (1855)]] alongside his father-in-law William Bashall who presented ''The [[Madrigal]]'', also by Horsley.{{cite journal|last1=Great Britain. Imperial commission, Paris universal exhibition|journal=Paris universal exhibition, 1855. Catalogue of the works exhibited in the British section of the exhibition, in French and English; together with exhibitors' prospectuses, prices current, &c. |date=1855|page=77|title=FINE ARTS DIVISION |url=https://archive.org/stream/parisuniversale01goog#page/n90/mode/2up/search/Beaux-Arts+|accessdate=13 November 2015|publisher=London, Chapman and Hall|location=University of Michigan}} Hick and Bashall used the same pair again for the 1857 [[Art Treasures Exhibition, Manchester 1857|Art Treasures Exhibition]] in Manchester with ''[[Cupid and Psyche]]'' by [[Benjamin West]] PRA{{cite journal|last1=Peck|first1=John|title=B. WEST P.R.A. |journal=Catalogue of the art treasures of the United Kingdom: collected at Manchester in 1857|date=1857|page=288|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogueofarttr00artt#page/n287/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=Getty Research Institute}} and ''Crossing the [[stream|Brook]]'' by [[Paul Falconer Poole]].{{cite journal|last1=Peck|first1=John|title=P.F. Poole A.R.A. |journal=Catalogue of the art treasures of the United Kingdom: collected at Manchester in 1857|date=1857|page=352|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogueofarttr00artt#page/n352/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=Getty Research Institute}} Hick was a force behind the movement that led to the formation of the [[Volunteer Force (Great Britain)|27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteers]] from the [[Bolton]] area, he was offered command, but declined;{{cite book|last1=Scholes|first1=James Christopher|editor1-last=Pemblett|editor1-first=William|title=HISTORY OF BOLTON: WITH MEMORIALS OF THE OLD PARISH CHURCH |date=1892|location=Bolton | publisher=The Daily Chronicle Office |page=451|url=https://archive.org/stream/historyboltonwi00schogoog#page/n198/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=18 November 2015}} The Regiment was formed on 15 November 1859 following tensions between the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] and [[Second French Empire|France]]{{cite web|title=The Lancashire Rifle Volunteers|url=http://www.lancashireinfantrymuseum.org.uk/the-lancashire-rifle-volunteers/|website=The Duke of Lancaster's Regiment, [[Lancashire Infantry Museum]]|accessdate=19 November 2015|date=2015}} and the out break of [[Second Italian War of Independence|war]] between France and the [[Austrian Empire]] during April of the same year.{{cite book|last=Grierson|first=James Moncrieff|title=Records of the Scottish volunteer force, 1859-1908|year=1909|publisher=W Blackwood|location=[[Edinburgh]]|pages=3–11|url=https://archive.org/stream/recordsofscottis00grieuoft#page/2/mode/2up|authorlink=James Grierson}} [[William Gray (Conservative politician)|William Gray MP]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]] (1814–1895) and former Mayor of Bolton became [[Lieutenant Colonel]] 1 January 1861;{{cite web|title=Lt Col William Gray|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/gray-w.html|website=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=19 November 2015|date=2015}}{{cite journal|title=27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteer Corps|journal=The London Gazette|date=15 January 1861|page=163|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/22471/page/163/data.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2015}} John Hick's nephew Benjamin Hick (1845–1882),{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Benjamin Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg05.htm#90|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044001/http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg05.htm#90|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} manager in [[Hick, Hargreaves & Co]],{{cite book|title=P. W. Pilling, ''Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets'' (Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, University of Liverpool, 1985)|pages=121, 451–452}} was made a Captain 16 March 1872,{{cite journal|title=27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteer Corps|journal=The London Gazette|date=29 March 1872|page=1680|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/22471/page/163/data.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2015}} resigning his commission about four years later 23 February 1876.{{cite journal|title=27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteer Corps|journal=The London Gazette|date=22 February 1876|page=816|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/22471/page/163/data.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2015}} ==Bolton Iron and Steel Company== In 1860 partners in [[B. Hick and Sons|B. Hick and Son]], John Hick and William Hargreaves joined Thomas Lever Rushton's brother-in-law Henry Sharp as partners in Sharp and Eckersley, formerly Rushton and Eckersley before Rushton's retirement from the firm in 1859. The three partners Sharp, Hick and Hargreaves formed the Bolton Iron & Steel Company;{{cite web|title=Thomas Lever Rushton|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/rushton-t-l.html|work=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=7 May 2015}} situated next door to Rothwell's [[Rothwell, Hick and Rothwell#Rothwell and Company|Union Foundry]] (now [[Bolton bus station]]) the company supplied basic metals required by the major manufacturers in the area.{{cite book|last1=O’Connor|first1=Denis|title=THE RISE OF BOLTON AS AN IMPORTANT ENGINEERING AND TEXTILE TOWN IN EARLY 1800 ENGLAND|page=60|url=http://www.torpedo150rijeka.org/docs/protorpedoEN/documents/14/1.0/Original.pdf}} [[Henry Bessemer|Bessemer]] [[Bessemer process|steel making]] began about 1860{{cite book|last1=Reed|first1=Brian|title=Crewe Locomotive Works and Its Men|date=1982|publisher=David & Charles|isbn=9780715382288|edition=Illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wzlPAAAAMAAJ&q=Bolton+iron+%26+steel+1860&dq=Bolton+iron+%26+steel+1860}} – four six-ton Bessemer converters were installed during the 1860s,{{cite book|last1=Erickson|first1=Charlotte|title=British Industrialists|date=1959|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=147|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0o2TmT8-544C&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=bolton+iron+and+steel+company+four+bessemer+converters#v=onepage&q=bolton%20iron%20and%20steel%20company%20four%20bessemer%20converters&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015|isbn=9780521049405}} and experiments with the [[Carl Wilhelm Siemens|Sieman]]'s [[Siemens-Martin process|open-hearth process]] began in 1867.{{cite book|last1=Erickson|first1=Charlotte|title=British Industrialists|date=1959|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=158|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0o2TmT8-544C&pg=PA158&dq=Siemens+open-hearth+process+in+1867+bolton+iron+and+steel#v=onepage&q=Siemens%20open-hearth%20process%20in%201867%20bolton%20iron%20and%20steel&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015|isbn=9780521049405}} [[Rolling (metalworking)|Rolling]], [[casting]] and [[forge|forging]] equipment was installed, its products included steel deck [[beam (structure)|beam]]s for ships and [[sheet metal]] for [[shovel]]s,{{cite book|last1=Timmins|first1=Geoffrey|title=Made in Lancashire: A History of Regional Industrialisation|date=1998|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=9780719045394|page=195|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hRANAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA195&lpg=PA195&dq=Made+in+Lancashire:+a+history+of+regional+industrialisation.++bolton+iron+and+steel#v=onepage&q=Made%20in%20Lancashire%3A%20a%20history%20of%20regional%20industrialisation.%20%20bolton%20iron%20and%20steel&f=false|edition=illustrated}} during 1865 Bolton Iron & Steel cast the largest [[anvil]] block made in England, weighing 210 tons. By 1869 the company was making open hearth [[steel]] and manufacturing [[steam hammer]]s to the design of [[Francis Webb (engineer)|Francis Webb]].{{cite web|title=Bolton Iron and Steel Co|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Bolton_Iron_and_Steel_Co|website=Grace's Guide|publisher=Grace's Guide Ltd|accessdate=6 December 2014}} Hick's nephew became a shareholder following incorporation on 9 June 1876.{{cite book|title=P. W. Pilling, ''Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets'' (Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, University of Liverpool, 1985)|pages=152, 158–160, 485, 521}} [[File:Mrs Margaret Hick.jpg|thumb|left|Mrs Margaret Hick by Francis Grant RA, presented at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]], May 1861.]] About 1861 society painter [[Francis Grant (artist)|Francis Grant]] produced portraits of John Hick and his wife Margaret, both works eventually hung together in the family home at [[Little Mitton|Mytton]] Hall.{{cite book|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=CATALOGUE OF THE PRINCIPLE PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, BOOKS, BRONZES, &C., AT MYTTON HALL, The Residence of John Hick, Esq. |date=1893|publisher=Ede, Dearberg & Co 40 QUEEN STREET CITY}} Hick was an associate of Bolton engineer, artist and photographer Reuben Mitchell (1812–1895), and pursued his own interest in photography,{{cite book|last1=MacLeod|first1=Christine|title=Heroes of Invention: Technology, Liberalism and British Identity, 1750-1914|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521873703|page=260|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZhMHZdm4U-QC&pg=PA260&lpg=PA260&dq=sans+pareil+john+hick+1864#v=onepage&q=sans%20pareil%20john%20hick%201864&f=false|accessdate=27 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Sims|title=Mitchell, Reuben |url=http://books.simsreed.com/photography/photography.php?category=photography&stk=41861|website=Sims Reed Rare Books|publisher=Sims Reed Rare Books Ltd|accessdate=10 June 2014}} he was also a supporter of the artists [[Copley Fielding]], [[William Powell Frith]], [[Patrick Nasmyth]], [[Samuel Prout]], [[Edward Matthew Ward]] and others; the engineer and artist [[James Nasmyth]] described John Hick as an "excellent friend".{{cite book|last=Nasmyth|first=James|title=James Nasmyth engineer: an autobiography, Edited by Samuel Smiles|year=1883|publisher=John Murray | location=[[Albemarle Street]], London|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/James_Nasmyth_by_James_Nasmyth:_Chronological_List#1848._Application_of_Hydraulic_Power_to_the_Punching_of_Large_Holes_in_Iron_Bars.2C_and_Plates_of_Great_Thickness. }} Hick wrote a history of [[Timothy Hackworth]]'s [[locomotive]] ''[[Sans Pareil]]'' and presented the restored engine to the [[Intellectual Property Office (United Kingdom)|Patent Office Museum]] (now the [[Science Museum (London)|Science Museum]]) in 1864,{{cite book|last1=Ahrons|first1=Ernest Leopold|title=The British steam railway locomotive, 1825-1925|date=1927|publisher=THE LOCOMOTIVE PUBLISHING COMPANY LIMITED|page=14|url=https://archive.org/stream/britishsteamrail00ahro#page/14/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=27 November 2015}} he also photographed William M. Gowland for [[Bennett Woodcroft]]. Gowland was driver of Hackworth's ''[[Timothy Hackworth#The Royal George|Royal George]]'' and driver of ''Sans Pareil'' at the [[Rainhill Trials]].{{cite web|title=Photograph portrait of William M. Gowland 1850-1864|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?t=objects&type=all&f=&s=william+gowland&record=0|website=Science Museum Group|accessdate=10 November 2016|date=1864}} ''Sans Pareil'' was previously owned by Hick's brother-in-law and eventual business partner [[John Hargreaves (early railway operator)|John Hargreaves Jr]] (1800–1874) who had the engine fully repaired and running on the [[Bolton and Leigh Railway]] in 1837.{{cite book|last1=SEKON|first1=G. A. | title=Evolution of the Stream Locomotive (1803 to 1898.)|date=1899|publisher=THE RAILWAY PUBLISHING CO., Ltd. | location=79 to 83 Temple Chambers, Temple Avenue, E.C., London |pages=34–35|url=http://www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/The_Evolution_of_the_Steam_Locomotive_1803_1000108809/43|accessdate=27 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Liverpool & Manchester Railway – Hackworth's "Sans Pareil"|url=http://www.railalbum.co.uk/early-railways/sans-pareil.htm|website=Rail Album|publisher=Parthenon Consultancy Limited|accessdate=27 November 2015|date=2010}} ''Sans Pareil'' is now housed at the [[National Railway Museum]]'s [[Shildon Locomotion Museum]] annexe.{{cite web|last1=Physick|first1=Liam|title=Sans Pareil|url=http://www.edgehillstation.co.uk/resources/sans-pareil/|website=EDGE HILL|publisher=Edge Hill Station|accessdate=27 November 2015|date=2015}}{{cite web|title=Timothy Hackworth – Railway Pioneer 1786–1850|url=http://www.railcentre.co.uk/RailHistory/Hackworth/Pages/HackworthPage2.html|website=Railcentre|publisher=J. Metcalfe|accessdate=27 November 2015|date=2015}} In 1867 Hick first published a paper, reprinted from ''[[The Engineer (magazine)|The Engineer]]'', 1 June 1866, ''Experiments on the Friction of the Leather Collars in [[Hydraulic Press]]es'', that expanded on the work of [[William John Macquorn Rankine|Dr William Rankine]], describing an important series of experiments carried out using a joint invention of Hick and Robert Lüthy (1840–1883),{{cite web|title=Robert Luthy|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Robert_Luthy|website=Grace's Guide|publisher=Institution of Mechanical Engineers|accessdate=22 March 2017|date=1884}} a [[Swiss people|Swiss]] engineer employed by Hick, and inventor of a hydraulic [[cotton]] packing press. Hick's father was the inventor of the self tightening collar, used universally in hydraulic pressess.{{cite journal|title=MR. HICK'S EXPERIMEN'TS ON 'THE FRICTION OF LEATHER COLLARS IN HYDRAULIC CY- LINDERS.|journal=The Engineer|date=1 June 1866|volume=21|pages=393–394|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/images/4/45/Er18660601.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=Experiments on the friction of the leather collars in hydraulic presses.|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Experiments-friction-hydraulic-presses-Conducted/dp/B000XD460E|website=Amazon|accessdate=18 March 2017|date=1867}}{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=EXPERIMENTS ON THE FRICTION COLLARS IN HYDRAULIC PRESSES|journal=Reprinted from ("THE ENGINEER")|date=1884|issue=Second Edition|url=https://archive.org/stream/experimentsonfr00hickgoog#page/n4/mode/2up|accessdate=18 March 2017|publisher=E & F. N. SPON CHARING CROSS.|location=University of Michigan}}{{cite book|title=P. W. Pilling, ''Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets'' (Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, University of Liverpool, 1985)|page=122}} ==Parliament== On [[United Kingdom general election, 1868|17 November 1868]] Hick was elected as Member of Parliament (MP) for [[Bolton (UK Parliament constituency)|Bolton]]. After election and to avoid a [[conflict of interest]], he immediately resigned his position within Hick, Hargreaves and Co., the firm were already in possession of government contracts,{{cite journal| author=Unknown |title=Memoirs |journal=1894 Institution of Mechanical Engineers: Obituaries|date=1894|volume=|pages=161–162|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/1894_Institution_of_Mechanical_Engineers:_Obituaries|accessdate=24 November 2015|issn=}} and withdrew from the Bolton Iron and Steel Company.{{cite book| first=P. W. | last=Pilling | title=Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets | publisher=Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, [[University of Liverpool]] | year=1985 |pages=118–119, 123–125, 158}} Hick [[United Kingdom general election, 1874|held the seat]] until [[United Kingdom general election, 1880|24 March 1880]]{{Rayment-hc|b|4|date=March 2012}} when as a result of ill-health, he chose not to stand for re-election.{{cite book|last=Clegg |first=James |title=ANNALS OF BOLTON, HISTORY, CHRONOLOGY, POLITICS, PARLIAMENTARY AND MUNICIPAL POLLS|date=1888|publisher=The Chronicle Office | location=Knowsley Street, Bolton |agency=Allen County Public Library Genealogy Center|page=184 |url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsofboltonhi00cleg#page/357/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=13 November 2015}} Hick was a [[liberal Conservative]] in favour of education based on religion, a supporter of the general principles of the [[Education Act 1870]] and an adherent to the view that religious and secular education should not be separated. As a Conservative he was a member of the [[Carlton Club|Carlton]], [[Conservative Club|Conservative]] and [[St Stephen's Club|St Stephen's]] Clubs.{{cite book|last1=Walford|first1=Edward|title=The county families of the United Kingdom; or, Royal manual of the titled and untitled aristocracy of England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland |date=1873| location=Allen County Public Library Genealogy Center | publisher=R. Hardwicke|page=496|url=https://archive.org/stream/countyfamiliesof13walf#page/496/mode/2up|accessdate=1 December 2015}} In May 1870 Hick chaired a [[Select committee (United Kingdom)|Select Committee]] to investigate [[boiler|steam-boiler]] [[Boiler explosions|explosions]]; following the report in August 1870, he introduced a [[Bill (law)|Bill]] "...to provide a more efficient remedy to persons injured and property damaged by the explosion of steam-boilers through [[negligence]]". In April 1871 he seconded a [[motion (democracy)|motion]] by Colonel [[Sir Walter Barttelot, 1st Baronet|Barttelot]] (1820–1893), Conservative MP for [[West Sussex (UK Parliament constituency)|Sussex Western]] 1860–1885, for a Select Committee "...to inquire into the merits of the [[Martini-Henry Rifle]]...whether it is the most suitable rifle as compared with others now manufactured to arm our troops with."{{cite web|title=MOTION FOR A SELECT COMMITTEE |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1871/apr/28/motion-for-a-select-committee#S3V0205P0_18710428_HOC_47|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=28 April 1871}} and debated ''Supply – [[British Army|Army]] Estimates'', June 1873 drawing attention to the improvement of [[Artillery|heavy ordnance]].{{cite web|title=SUPPLY—ARMY ESTIMATES |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1873/jun/23/supply-army-estimates#S3V0216P0_18730623_HOC_73|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=23 June 1873}} As a parliamentarian he was frequently consulted by Government on subjects relating to [[armaments]] and the construction of boilers for [[War vessel|war-vessels]]. Hick also served on a Select Committee appointed June 1874 to investigate the testing of [[chain|chain cable]] and [[anchors]] for the [[British navy|Navy]], and debated ''[[Classification of railway accidents|Railway accidents]] – the adoption of [[continuous brakes]]'', June 1879.{{cite web|title=RAILWAYS—RAILWAY ACCIDENTS — THE ADOPTION OF CONTINUOUS BRAKES —OBSERVATIONS |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1879/jun/13/railways-railway-accidents-the-adoption#S3V0246P0_18790613_HOC_61|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=13 June 1879}} As a director of LNWR, Hick defended the railway's position, stating he "regarded all automatic machinery with distrust".{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Kevin|title=Brief Biographies of Major Mechanical Engineers|url=http://www.steamindex.com/people/engrs.htm#surnha|website=STEAMINDEX|accessdate=21 January 2016|date=2015}} He was [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for the [[County Palatine]] from 1870 until death{{cite book|last1=SPIKE|first1=ARCHIBALD|title=BIBLIOGRAPHIA BOLTONIENSIS: being a bibliography, with biographical details of Bolton authors, and the books written by them from 1550 to 1912; books about Bolton; and those printed and published in the town from 1785 to date|date=1913|publisher=MANCHESTER: THE UNIVERSITY PRESS|page=82|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924029566019#page/n103/mode/2up|accessdate=18 December 2015}} and on taking up residence at Mytton Hall, [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|Justice of the Peace]] for [[Whalley, Lancashire]], he rejoined the [[Institute of Mechanical Engineers]] in 1871, proposed by [[Frederick Bramwell]]{{cite book|title=Membership records|location=Institute of Mechanical Engineers}} and elected a Member of Council in 1872, a Vice-President of the institute from 1874 to 1876. [[File:Mytton Hall.jpg|thumb|Mytton Hall – entrance c.1893, by Thomas Parkinson, Bolton.]] For his contribution to the 1873 [[Annual International Exhibitions (London 1871–74)|International Exhibition]] at [[South Kensington]] Hick was presented with a Bronze Medal,{{cite web|title=COMMEMORATIVE MEDALS, BRITISH HISTORICAL MEDALS|url=http://www.baldwin.co.uk/media/cms/auction-archive/auction-a214/BALDWINS%20Argentum%20Auction%20-%20June%202014%20-%2002%20-%20COMMEMORATIVE%20MEDALS%20AND%20BANKNOTES.pdf|website=Baldwin's|publisher=A. H. Baldwin & Sons Ltd|accessdate=6 November 2014|location=Lot No. 384}} he was a member of the ''Permanent Committee for the Representation for British Pictures'' for the 1874 International Exhibition with fellow MPs [[Henry Bolckow]], [[Sir Alexander Brown, 1st Baronet|Alexander Brown]], [[Henry Eaton, 1st Baron Cheylesmore|Henry Eaton]], [[Joshua Fielden (politician)|Joshua Fielden]], [[William Graham (Glasgow MP)|William Graham]], [[John Snowdon Henry]], [[John Pender]] and others.{{cite journal|title=APPENDIX H. FORM NO.11. LONDON INTERNATIONAL EXHIBITION OF 1874. Permanent Committee for the Representation of British Pictures|journal=Victoria Government Gazette|date=7 November 1873|issue= 79|page=1951|url=http://gazette.slv.vic.gov.au/images/1873/V/general/79.pdf}} On 15 March 1879, towards the end of his time as an [[Member of Parliament|MP]], John Hick along with C.D. Abel, Colonel [[Frederick Beaumont]] (1833–1899) [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] MP for [[South Durham]] 1868–1880, F. Bolton, [[Alexander Brogden]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]] (1825–1892) of [[John Brogden and Sons]], Liberal MP 1868–1885 for [[Wednesbury]], J.T. Jones and J. Turay registered the Aqueous Works and [[Exploration diamond drilling|Diamond Rock-boring]] Company (Limited), Crown Works, Guildford Street, York Road, [[Lambeth]].{{Citation|title=The Mining journal, railway and commercial gazette:forming a complete record of the proceedings of all public companies|publication-date=15 March 1879|publisher=H. English|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/19188816|accessdate=13 November 2015|page=252}} The company "...bought out and patented the system of using diamonds for boring".,{{cite web|title=ARTESIAN WELLS |url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/File:1891_KentSurreySussex4_i0793.png|website=Graces's Guide|publisher=Grace's Guide|accessdate=13 November 2015|page=24|date=1890}} Hick was elected a member of the [[Iron and Steel Institute]] the same year.{{cite journal|last1=UNKNOWN|title=''OBITUARY.''|journal=1894 Iron and Steel Institute: Obituaries|date=1894|volume=|page=389|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/1894_Iron_and_Steel_Institute:_Obituaries|accessdate=25 November 2015|issn=}} The Aqueous Works and Diamond Rock-boring Company was liquidated about 1892.{{cite journal|journal=The London Gazette|title=Aqueous Works and Exploration Diamond Rock-boring Company|date=26 February 1892|page=1145|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/26262/page/1145/data.pdf|accessdate=13 November 2015}} ==Pollution trial== After leaving parliament Hick and [[Lieutenant Colonel|Lt-Col.]] [[High Sheriff of Lancashire|Ralph John Aspinall]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]], campaigned against the pollution and poisoning of [[salmon]] and [[trout]] in the [[River Ribble]] and its tributories by local industry; Hick raised the issue of pollution in the Ribble during the [[third reading]] of the [[Rivers Pollution Prevention Act 1876]].{{cite web|title=[BILL 276.] THIRD READING |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1876/aug/04/bill-276-third-reading#S3V0231P0_18760804_HOC_172|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=4 August 1876}} Aspinall and Hick fought a publicised and successful legal battle in the [[Court of Chancery]] against the [[cotton mill]]s of [[Mitchell and Carlisle]] during July 1880 leading to a landmark judgement that set a precedent for controlling environmental pollution.{{cite web|last1=Kingsley|first1=Nicholas|title=Aspinall of Standen Hall|url=http://landedfamilies.blogspot.co.uk/2016/04/214-aspinall-of-standen-hall.html|website=Landed families of Britain and Ireland|publisher=Nicholas Kingsley|accessdate=11 May 2016|date=22 April 2016}} The river ran close to Mytton Hall where [[landlord]] Aspinall held the [[Fishing license|fishing rights]] and John Hick was lessee from 1874.{{cite web|last1=Unknown|title=Mitton Hall Mitton, Lancashire – Heritage Statement|url=https://www.ribblevalley.gov.uk/planx_downloads/Heritage_Statement.pdf|website=Ribble Valley Borough Council|publisher=JWRC Chartered Building Surveyors & Historic Building Consultants|accessdate=27 November 2015|page=8|date=October 2012}} The trial was presided over by the [[Chancellor of the High Court|Vice-Chancellor]] of England, Sir [[James Bacon (judge)|James Bacon]].{{cite news|title=HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE. CHANCERY DIVISION. (Before VICE-CHANCELLOR SIR J.BACON.) ASPINALL V. MITCHELL|issue=29927|publisher=The Times|date=7 July 1880|page=4}}{{cite news|title=HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE. CHANCERY DIVISION. (Before VICE-CHANCELLOR SIR J.BACON.) ASPINALL V. MITCHELL|issue=29945|publisher=The Times|date=28 July 1880|page=4}} In December 1880 Hick and Aspinall received presentations at Mytton Hall from the local [[angling]] community in recognition of "...their services in preventing pollution to the River Ribble and its tributories".{{cite book|last=Clegg |first=James |title=ANNALS OF BOLTON, HISTORY, CHRONOLOGY, POLITICS, PARLIAMENTARY AND MUNICIPAL POLLS|date=1888| location=Bolton | publisher=The Chronicle Office, Knowlsey Street |agency=Allen County Public Library Genealogy Center|page=186|url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsofboltonhi00cleg#page/361/mode/2up/search/HICK|accessdate=13 November 2015}} ==Science Museum== During 1887 Hick was a member of the mechanical collections committee chaired by [[John Slagg|John Slagg, MP]] with other experts and politicians; [[William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong|Sir William Armstrong]], [[Joseph Bazalgette|Sir Joseph Bazelgette]], [[James Brunlees]], [[Edward Alfred Cowper|Edward Cowper]], Professor T. M. Goodeve, [[Charles Hutton Gregory|Sir Charles Gregory]], [[James Howard (agriculturalist)|James Howard, MP]], [[Charles Manby]], [[John Hinde Palmer]] (d.1884), [[Edward James Reed|Sir Edward Reed, MP]] and [[Bernhard Samuelson|Sir Bernhard Samuelson, MP]] established with several committees for the purpose of advising a central committee appointed by the Treasury to investigate the forming of a [[Science Museum (London)|Science Museum]] and [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Gallery of Portraits]] in [[South Kensington]], situated between the [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]] and what was to be the [[Imperial Institute]].{{cite news|author=From a Correspondent |title=The Need of a Science Museum |issue=32137| newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=29 July 1887|page=4}} ==Death== [[File:LNWR engine No.20 John Hick.jpg|thumb|LNWR engine no. 20 ''John Hick'', built at [[Crewe Works]].{{cite book|last1=Steel|first1=Wilfred. L|title=The History of the London & North Western Railway|date=1914|publisher="The Railway and TravelMonthly"|location=University of California|page=465|url=https://archive.org/stream/historylondonno00steegoog#page/n478/mode/2up|accessdate=4 February 2016|chapter=CONCERNING LOCOMOTIVE MATTERS}}]] Previously of Hill Top, [[Belmont, Lancashire]] Hick died at the age of 78 after some months of failing health when living at [[Little Mitton|Mytton]] Hall, [[Whalley, Lancashire]] and [[Lezayre]], [[Isle of Man]],{{cite book|last=Kermode, M.A. |first=Canon R. D. |title=THE ANNALS OF KIRK CHRIST LEZAYRE|date=1954|publisher=THE NORRIS MODERN PRESS LTD. | location=Victoria Street, Douglas |url=http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/ker1954/ch14.htm |accessdate=2 December 2015|chapter=XIV – ST. STEPHEN'S, SULBY}} where he was also a [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|Justice of the Peace]].{{cite book|last1=Walford|first1=Edward|title=The county families of the United Kingdom; or, Royal manual of the titled and untitled aristocracy of England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland |date=1919| location=London | publisher=R. Hardwicke|page=654|url=https://archive.org/stream/countyfamiliesof591919walf#page/654/mode/2up |accessdate=2 December 2015}} Like his father Benjamin, John Hick accumulated a large and valuable collection of art works, some of which was [[inheritance|inherited]], others purchased from the auction of [[Benjamin Hick]]'s [[Estate (law)|estate]] in 1843,{{cite journal|title=SALE OF AN IMPORTANT AND GENUINE COLLECTION OF PICTURES, DRAWINGS, ENGRAVINGS, BRONZES &c|journal=The Art-Union|date=1 January 1843|volume=|page=26|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CGZRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=benjamin+hick+art+journal#v=onepage&q=benjamin%20hick%20art%20journal&f=false |accessdate=23 January 2014}}{{cite journal|editor1-last=Cave (URBAN)|editor1-first=Edward (SILVANUS)|authorlink=Edward Cave|title=SALES OF PICTURES|journal=The Gentleman's Magazine|date=1843|volume=XIX |pages=507–508|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6CZIAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA507&lpg=PA507&dq=hick+sale+of+pictures+The+gentleman%27s+magazine#v=onepage&q=hick%20sale%20of%20pictures%20The%20gentleman%27s%20magazine&f=false|accessdate=20 May 2015| location=London | publisher=WILLIAM PICKERING; JOHN BOWYER NICHOLS AND SON }} and devoted his final years at Mytton Hall to compiling an elaborately illustrated catalogue of the collection;{{cite journal|author=Unknown |title=Obituary, John Hick, 1815-1894|journal=Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers|date=1894|volume=117|issue=1894|pages=379–380|url=http://www.icevirtuallibrary.com/doi/pdf/10.1680/imotp.1894.19959|accessdate=13 November 2015|issn=1753-7843|doi=10.1680/imotp.1894.19959}} some of these works were auctioned by [[Christie's]] during June and July 1909{{cite journal|title=A RECORD OF SALE PRICES AT CHRISTIE'S DURING THE SEASON|journal=Art Prices Current|date=1909|volume=II|issue=1908–9|pages=xix, 229, 278|url=https://archive.org/stream/artpricescurrent02lond#page/278/mode/1up/search/hick|accessdate=13 November 2015|publisher=London, Offices of the Fine Art Trade Journal|location=Philadelphia Museum of Art, Library}} following Rebecca Hick's death in 1908.{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Rebecca Maria Ashworth|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg04.htm#131|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite journal|title=Mrs. REBECCA MARIA HICK, Deceased |journal=The London Gazette|date=26 January 1909|page=692|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/28218/page/692/data.pdf|accessdate=4 December 2015}} The Hick library at Mytton Hall was dispersed at Capes Dunne & Co. [[Manchester]] in November 1909.{{cite journal|last1=Butterworth|first1=Walter|title=Henry Leverseege – the Ancoats artist|journal=PAPERS OF THE Manchester Literary Club|date=1920|volume=XLVI |pages= 14–15|url=https://archive.org/stream/papersman46mancuoft#page/14/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=7 May 2015|publisher=SHERRATT & HUGHES Manchester: 34 Cross Street|location=Robarts – [[University of Toronto]], Canada }} From the year of his death the [[London North Western Railway]] (LNWR) produced 10 [[steam locomotives]] of the [[LNWR John Hick Class|''John Hick'' Class]] (1894–1912); a [[Francis Webb (engineer)|Francis Webb]] design of [[2-2-2-2]] configuration,{{cite web|title=John Hick Class|url=http://www.lnwrs.org.uk/PassLocos/PassLoco.php?loco=09|website=London and North Western Railway Society, Passenger Engines of the LNWR|publisher=LNWR Society|accessdate=13 November 2014|date=1914}} engine No. 20 named ''John Hick''. The following 9 engines were named after [[engineers]] and inventors, principally from the [[Industrial Revolution|industrial]] and [[Second industrial revolution]]: No. 1505 ''[[Richard Arkwright]]'', No. 1512 ''[[Henry Cort]]'', No. 1534 ''[[William Froude]]'', No. 1535 ''[[Henry Maudslay]]'', No. 1536 ''[[Hugh Myddelton]]'', No. 1548 ''[[John Penn (engineer)|John Penn]]'', No. 1549 ''[[John Rennie the Younger|John Rennie]]'', No. 1557 ''[[Thomas Savery]]'' and No. 1559 ''[[William Siemens]]''.{{cite magazine|last1=Hambleton | first1=F.C. |title=Webb compounds: "John Hick" class L.N.W.R. |magazine=The Locomotive Magazine and Railway Carriage and Wagon Review|date=15 February 1940|volume=46|issue=570|pages=36–37| location=London | publisher=Locomotive Pub. Co., 1896–1959 }}{{cite book|last1=Baxter, Bertram|editor1-last=Baxter|editor1-first=David|title=British Locomotive Catalogue 1825–1923, Volume 2B: London and North Western Railway and its constituent companies |date=1979|publisher=Ashbourne, Derbyshire: Moorland Publishing Company |isbn=0903485842|pages=196–197}}{{cite book|last1=Sharman|first1=M. |title=The London and North Western Railway: A Selection of 7mm Locomotive Drawings|date=1986|publisher=Oakwood Press & Video Library|isbn=9780853613152|edition=illustrated}} Hick was unique in that he was the only LNWR director to have a locomotive class named after him ''[[wikt:in memoriam|in memoriam]]''.{{cite book|last1=Baxter, Bertram|editor1-last=Baxter|editor1-first=David|title=British Locomotive Catalogue 1825–1923, Volume 2A: London and North Western Railway and its constituent companies |date=1978|publisher=Ashbourne, Derbyshire: Moorland Publishing Company |isbn=0903485516|pages=}}{{cite book|last1=Baxter, Bertram|editor1-last=Baxter|editor1-first=David|title=British Locomotive Catalogue 1825–1923, Volume 2B: London and North Western Railway and its constituent companies |date=1979|publisher=Ashbourne, Derbyshire: Moorland Publishing Company |isbn=0903485842|pages=}} Following withdrawal of the ''John Hick'' Class in 1912, during the month of the anniversary of Hick's death, February 1913, 5 of 6 names were transferred to the LNWR [[LNWR George the Fifth Class|''George the Fifth'' Class]], locomotive No. 752 named ''John Hick'', serving up to 1935 with the [[London Midland and Scottish Railway]] (LMS).{{cite web|title=JOHN HICK|url=http://www.brdatabase.info/locoqry.php?action=locodata&type=S&id=125311&loco=752|website=BRDatabase – Complete BR Locomotive Database 1948-1997|publisher=BRDatabase.info|accessdate=18 December 2015|date=2013}} ==See also== *[[George Forrester and Company]] *[[Johann Georg Bodmer]] *[[Moscow Contemporary Art Center Winzavod#Moscow Bavaria|Gerasim Ivanovich Khludov]]{{cite book|last1=Strachan, Bolton|first1=Edward, Roy|title=ROMANOVS TO REVOLUTION: LIFE IN IMPERIAL RUSSIA 1721-1917|date=2016|publisher=Sphinx Fine Art|pages=24,
